titleStmt.title: Variants of Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) open syllable before ī - CaCīC
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) open syllable before ī - CaCīC.

item.label: a > i kibīr
item.desc: also includes raising to u or to ə in different environments

item.label: a > a and i become schwa for the Maghreb

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers show consistent raising of short medial a in unstressed open syllable before ī.

In this pattern the conditioning seems to be consistent as shown in the preservation of a in ġarīb (strange), qalīl (a little), ṭawīl (long), xafīfa (light. F) and gaṛīḅa (near. F). Nevertheless, probably due to influence from BEI, in this pattern a is sometimes elided altogether, often in rather frequent adjectives such as mnīḥ (good) kbīr (big) and ktīr (a lot).

Young speakers and some middle-aged speakers do not show raising of short medial a in unstressed open syllable, unlike Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers, but rather show elision altogether of the vowel, except for the cases where a is preserved when preceded by guttural and emphatic consonants, e.g. ṭawīl (long), ḥarīr (silk), etc.
Conditioning - Raising does not happen when in gutural or emphatic environments.

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:63 notes in a section entitled Treatment of Pretonic *a in CaCīC that: “In true Bedouin dialects, *a is maintained in the environment of back consonants as above, but raised to /i/ or /u/ elsewhere.”

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 note that: "In Bedouin dialects, *a in pretonic syllable or the first open syllable of a word is raised to /i/ or /u/ in the environment of front consonants, respectively labials. In sedentary dialects this shift is rather restricted to some cases."

Behnstedt & Geva-Kleinberger 2019:63 notes in a section entitled Treatment of Pretonic *a in CaCīC that: “In true Bedouin dialects, *a is maintained in the environment of back consonants as above, but raised to /i/ or /u/ elsewhere.”

In environments with gutural and emphatic consonants, a is kept.
Conditioning: a is kept in gutural and emphatic environments.
Deducted from examples.
Conditioning: a is kept in gutural and emphatic environments.
Deducted from examples.
Conditioning of gutural and emphatic consonants do not always block the fall of a, e.g. ṭḥīn (flour) but sometimes prompt the preservation of a, e.g. faʔīr (poor).

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."
Conditioning: In the environment of gutural and emphatic consonants, a remains.

Younes (2014:361-362) notes that: "Nous constatons que la présence d’une vélaire engendre une élévation assez centralisée tandis que dans un environnement plus neutre, la voyelle /a/ s’élèvera vers le /i/. Ceci est tout de même soumis à quelques exceptions puisque nous avons noté : dǝxīl « personne trouvant refuge », mǝdīn « ayant une dette (m.) » mǝsīr « chemin, trajet ». Tel que relevé, il semble que la présence d’une labiale dans un contexte emphatique tire la voyelle /a/ vers /u/ : ṭuẉīla « longue, haute ». Also he notes: "De manière analogue à ce qui se passe dans les autres parlers nomades d’Orient, nous observons une inhibition systématique de l’imāla si C1 correspond à /ʾ/, /ʿ/, /h/, /ḥ/, /ġ/ ou /x/".
The author states that in plain syllables the a of the faʕīl pattern is raised

In guttural environments.
According to the author, the distinction between short and long vowels are difficult to attest, in most cases, supposedly long vowels are marked as short ones.
According to the author, the distinction between short and long vowels are difficult to attest, in most cases, supposedly long vowels are marked as short ones.
Some CaCīC(a) forms are raised, some are not, and others can deliberately be raised as gadīm/gidīm.
Some CaCīC(a) forms are raised, some are not, and others can deliberately be raised as gadīm/gidīm.

This raising occurs regularly, yet it remains optional. It is only inhibited by ʕ and is less regular when back fricatives precede or follow a, although it may take place in such positions, especially when following ʕ.
Raising is mainly absent when ʕ, ġ, ḥ or x precedes.
Some CaCīC(a) forms are raised, some are not, and others can deliberately be raised as gadīm/gidīm.

not after gutturals, e.g. ʕatīǧ old
but samīn fat
not with gutturals, baxīl stingy
but buxīl stingy
not after gutturals: ġalīḏ̣ thick
not after gutturals: ʕažín dough
